elements.content: When [Cu3(phis)3](ClO4)3, obtained from Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O with the Na+ or K+ salt of the phis anion (Hphis = N-(2-pyridylmethyl)-l-histidine), is reacted with LiClO4, the tricopper cationic structure rearranged to accommodate a Li+ ion to form [(ClO4)Li{Cu3(phis)3}](ClO4)3 which can also be prepared directly by reacting Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O with the Li+ salt of the phis anion.
elements.clean_text: When [Cu3(phis)3](ClO4)3, obtained from Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O with the Na+ or K+ salt of the phis anion (Hphis = N-(2-pyridylmethyl)-l-histidine), is reacted with LiClO4, the tricopper cationic structure rearranged to accommodate a Li+ ion to form [(ClO4)Li{Cu3(phis)3}](ClO4)3 which can also be prepared directly by reacting Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O with the Li+ salt of the phis anion.

elements.content: When [Cu3(phis)3](ClO4)3, obtained from Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O and a Na+ or K+ salt of phis (Hphis = N-(2-pyridylmethyl)-l-histidine), is reacted with LiClO4, the structure of the tricopper cation reorganized to accommodate a Li+ ion to form [(ClO4)Li{Cu3(phis)3}](ClO4)3.
elements.clean_text: When [Cu3(phis)3](ClO4)3, obtained from Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O and a Na+ or K+ salt of phis (Hphis = N-(2-pyridylmethyl)-l-histidine), is reacted with LiClO4, the structure of the tricopper cation reorganized to accommodate a Li+ ion to form [(ClO4)Li{Cu3(phis)3}](ClO4)3.

elements.content: Metallacrowns (MCs) with a variety of structural types are usually prepared in quantitative yields by a self-assembly process. A majority of the metallacrowns are robust and retain their structures in solution, a property which can be used for exchange reactions with metal ions and anions. However, the selectivity is determined by the cavity size of the metallacrown ethers and the radii of the ions used. Although the ion exchange reactions are very similar to those known for the classical crown ether, the field of inorganic host−guest chemistry is still in its infancy. In the course of exploring the coordination chemistry of Cu(II) compounds containing reduced Schiff base ligands, we have assembled two metallacrown cations that are structurally different in the presence and absence of a Li+ in the cavity. These metallacrown cations are very labile and dissociate into various oligomeric species in solution.
elements.clean_text: Metallacrowns (MCs) with a variety of structural types are usually prepared in quantitative yields by a self-assembly process. A majority of the metallacrowns are robust and retain their structures in solution, a property which can be used for exchange reactions with metal ions and anions. However, the selectivity is determined by the cavity size of the metallacrown ethers and the radii of the ions used. Although the ion exchange reactions are very similar to those known for the classical crown ether, the field of inorganic host-guest chemistry is still in its infancy. In the course of exploring the coordination chemistry of Cu(II) compounds containing reduced Schiff base ligands, we have assembled two metallacrown cations that are structurally different in the presence and absence of a Li+ in the cavity. These metallacrown cations are very labile and dissociate into various oligomeric species in solution.

elements.content: The ligand Hphis·HCl (Hphis = N-(2-pyridylmethyl)-l-histidine shown in Figure ), prepared by a similar method as that described for Hpgly·HCl, is very hygroscopic. Hence, it was prepared in situ as the potassium salt of phis and reacted with Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O in 1:1 molar ratio to yield dark blue crystals of [Cu3(phis)3](ClO4)3·2H2O (1·2H2O)8 which has been characterized by X-ray crystallography. In the structure of the trinuclear cation, each Cu(II) is surrounded by a phis ligand in a meridonal fashion, and the donor atoms occupy the base of the square pyramid along with another carboxylate oxygen from the neighboring cation (Figure ). The apical position of the distorted square pyramid is occupied by the oxygen atoms of the carboxylate group of the chelating phis ligand. The Cu−Oaxial distances 2.65(1) Å (Cu(1)−O(1)), 2.54(1) Å (Cu(2)−O(3)), and 2.39(1) Å (Cu(3)−O(5)) are weak. The oxygen atoms O(1) and O(3) are bridging Cu(II) atoms while O(2) and O(4) atoms are nonbonded. This makes the cavity in the ring very small, and the shortest distance, 3.033 Å, is between O(1) and O(5). This [8-MC-3] metallacrown is very unsymmetrical with Cu···Cu distances, 3.860, 4.310, and 5.273 Å. Such copper compounds have been used as a structural model for the trinuclear site in ascorbate oxidase from green zucchini.
elements.clean_text: The ligand Hphis⋅HCl (Hphis = N-(2-pyridylmethyl)-l-histidine shown in Figure ), prepared by a similar method as that described for Hpgly⋅HCl, is very hygroscopic. Hence, it was prepared in situ as the potassium salt of phis and reacted with Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O in 1:1 molar ratio to yield dark blue crystals of [Cu3(phis)3](ClO4)3⋅2H2O (1⋅2H2O)8 which has been characterized by X-ray crystallography. In the structure of the trinuclear cation, each Cu(II) is surrounded by a phis ligand in a meridonal fashion, and the donor atoms occupy the base of the square pyramid along with another carboxylate oxygen from the neighboring cation (Figure ). The apical position of the distorted square pyramid is occupied by the oxygen atoms of the carboxylate group of  the chelating phis ligand. The Cu-Oaxial distances 2.65(1) Å (Cu(1)-O(1)), 2.54(1) Å (Cu(2)-O(3)), and 2.39(1) Å (Cu(3)-O(5)) are weak. The oxygen atoms O(1) and O(3) are bridging Cu(II) atoms while O(2) and O(4) atoms are nonbonded. This makes the cavity in the ring very small, and the shortest distance, 3.033 Å, is between O(1) and O(5). This [8-MC-3] metallacrown is very unsymmetrical with Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances, 3.860, 4.310, and 5.273 Å. Such copper compounds have been used as a structural model for the trinuclear site in ascorbate oxidase from green zucchini.

elements.content: Ligand Hphis (top left-hand corner) and a perspective view of1. Selected distances (Å) and angles (deg):  Cu(1)−N(3) 1.93(1), Cu(1)−O(6) 1.97(1), Cu(1)−N(2) 2.00(1), Cu(1)−N(1) 2.01(1), Cu(2)−N(7) 1.93(2), Cu(2)−O(1) 1.991(9), Cu(2)−N(5) 1.99(1), Cu(2)−N(6) 2.02(1), Cu(3)−O(3) 1.90(1), Cu(3)−N(11) 1.94(2), Cu(3)−N(9) 1.96(1), Cu(3)−N(10) 1.98(2), Cu(3)−O(5) 2.39(1), O(6)−Cu(1)−N(2) 175.0(6), N(3)−Cu(1)−N(1) 170.4(5), N(7)−Cu(2)−N(5) 168.2(6), O(1)−Cu(2)−N(6) 157.8(5), N(11)−Cu(3)−N(9) 163.6(6), O(3)−Cu(3)−N(10) 160.4(6).

The compound [(ClO4)Li{Cu3(phis)3}](ClO4)3·3H2O (2·3H2O) has been isolated when a molar equivalent of LiClO4 was added to 1. The same compound could also be obtained from the lithium salt of phis and Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O in a 1:1 molar ratio. The crystal structure shows that the asymmetric unit consists of the [Li(ClO4){Cu3(phis)3}]3+ cation, three strongly hydrogen bonded lattice water molecules, and three perchlorate anions interacting with the cations and lattice waters. A perspective view of the cation is shown in Figure . In this trinuclear cation, phis anions are bonded to Cu(II) centers in mer fashion similar to 1. The donor atoms occupy three corners of the square plane which is completed by the exogenous oxygens from the neighboring Cu(phis) moiety. The pyridyl and the imidazole rings are also roughly in plane with the CuN3O plane. The trinuclear cation has the shape of a cone in which the phenyl rings are on the top as in 1. The N−H protons of the imidazole groups at the bottom are hydrogen bonded to oxygen atoms of the three water molecules. The bottom of the cone does not appear to be completely closed as inferred from the O···O distances, 3.397−3.641 Å.
elements.clean_text: The compound [(ClO4)Li{Cu3(phis)3}](ClO4)3⋅3H2O (2⋅3H2O) has been isolated when a molar equivalent of LiClO4 was added to 1. The same compound could also be obtained from the lithium salt of phis and Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O in a 1:1 molar ratio. The crystal structure shows that the asymmetric unit consists of the [Li(ClO4){Cu3(phis)3}]3+ cation, three strongly hydrogen bonded lattice water molecules, and three perchlorate anions interacting with the cations and lattice waters. A perspective view of the cation is shown in Figure . In this trinuclear cation, phis anions are bonded to Cu(II) centers in mer fashion similar to 1. The donor atoms occupy three corners of the square plane which is completed by the exogenous oxygens from the neighboring Cu(phis) moiety. The pyridyl and the imidazole rings are also roughly in plane with the CuN3O plane. The trinuclear cation has the shape of a cone in which the phenyl rings are on the top as in 1. The N-H protons of the imidazole groups at the bottom are hydrogen bonded to oxygen atoms of the three water molecules. The bottom of the cone does not appear to be completely closed as inferred from the O⋅⋅⋅O distances, 3.397-3.641 Å.

elements.content: The three endogenous carbonyl oxygen atoms in the [Cu3(phis)3]3+ cation are bonded to a Li(I) atom. The fourth distorted tetrahedral corner at Li(I) is completed by an oxygen atom of the disordered ClO4 - anion. The [Li{Cu3(phis)3}]4+ cation has an idealized C 3 symmetry with three crystallographically independent Cu(II) centers. It is obvious that the [Cu3(phis)3]3+ cation, [8-MC-3], has structurally reorganized to accommodate a lithium cation. Such dependency of the structure of the metallamacrocycles on the nature of guest molecules has been observed by Raymond, Fujita, Stang, and Lehn. Unlike 2, the [15-MC-3] metallacrowns characterized by Saalfrank and co-workers have been found to be planar and form both coronate and sandwich compounds.
elements.clean_text: The three endogenous carbonyl oxygen atoms in the [Cu3(phis)3]3+ cation are bonded to a Li(I) atom. The fourth distorted tetrahedral corner at Li(I) is completed by an oxygen atom of the disordered ClO4 - anion. The [Li{Cu3(phis)3}]4+ cation has an idealized C 3 symmetry with three crystallographically independent Cu(II) centers. It is obvious that the [Cu3(phis)3]3+ cation, [8-MC-3], has structurally reorganized to accommodate a lithium cation. Such dependency of the structure of the metallamacrocycles on the nature of guest molecules has been observed by Raymond, Fujita, Stang, and Lehn. Unlike 2, the [15-MC-3] metallacrowns characterized by Saalfrank and co-workers have been found to be planar and form both coronate and sandwich compounds.

elements.content: In the absence of a base, Hphis reacts with Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O to form a 1D coordination polymeric compound [Cu(phisH)(H2O)](ClO4)2, 3, Figure . In the cation, the Cu(II) center is five-coordinate, with the tridentate phis ligand bonded in a mer fashion at the square base and the fourth position completed by a carboxylate oxygen from the neighboring repeating unit. A water molecule at the apex completes the distorted square pyramidal geometry at the Cu(II) center. The second carboxylate oxygen atom participates in intermolecular bonding to Cu(II) which generates a one-dimensional zigzag polymeric structure. Compound 3 also resulted when the pH of the solution containing 1 or 2 is adjusted to a pH of 3−4.
elements.clean_text: In the absence of a base, Hphis reacts with Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O to form a 1D coordination polymeric compound [Cu(phisH)(H2O)](ClO4)2, 3, Figure . In the cation, the Cu(II) center is five-coordinate, with the tridentate phis ligand bonded in a mer fashion at the square base and the fourth position completed by a carboxylate oxygen from the  neighboring repeating unit. A water molecule at the apex completes the distorted square pyramidal geometry at the Cu(II) center. The second carboxylate oxygen atom participates in intermolecular bonding to Cu(II) which generates a one-dimensional zigzag polymeric structure. Compound 3 also resulted when the pH of the solution containing 1 or 2 is adjusted to a pH of 3-4.

elements.content: Segment of the 1D polymeric cation in3. Selected distance (Å) and angles (deg):  Cu(1)−N(1) 1.989(5), Cu(1)−N(2) 1.992(5), Cu(1)−O(1) 1.987(4), Cu(1)−O(2)a 1.938(4), Cu(1)−O(3) 2.341(7), N(1)−Cu(1)−O(1) 165.3(2), N(2)−Cu(1)−O(2)a 173.4(2). Symmetry operator:  a, x + 1/2, −y + 1/2, −z + 1.
elements.clean_text: 3  Segment of the 1D polymeric cation in3. Selected distance (Å) and angles (deg): Cu(1)-N(1) 1.989(5), Cu(1)-N(2) 1.992(5), Cu(1)-O(1) 1.987(4), Cu(1)-O(2)a 1.938(4), Cu(1)-O(3) 2.341(7), N(1)-Cu(1)-O(1) 165.3(2), N(2)-Cu(1)-O(2)a 173.4(2). Symmetry operator: a, x + 1/2, -y + 1/2, -z + 1.

elements.content: The ES mass spectrum of 3 exhibits a major band at m/z 408 originating from the [Cu(phisH)(ClO4)]+ ion while the ES mass spectrum of 2 in MeOH shows the presence of various dissociated species including [Cu(phis)(MeOH)3(H2O)]+ (m/z 422.1, 100%), [Cu2phis)2]2+ (m/z 309.2, 46%), [Cu3(phis)3(ClO4)]2+ (m/z 512.7, 30%), [Hphis·H3O]+ (m/z 263.4, 25%), [Cu2(phis)2(ClO4)]+ (m/z 716.9, 17%), [Cu3(phis)3(ClO4)2]+ (m/z 1123.9, 17%), and [Cu(phis)(CH3CN)(H2O)]+ (m/z 368, 15%). The ES-MS of 1 also exhibits the presence of several dissociated species such as [Cu(phis)(CH3CN)(H2O)]+ (m/z 368, 100%), [Cu2phis)2]2+ (m/z 309.2, 60%), [Cu(phis)(ClO4)(MeOH)2(H3O)]+ (m/z 492.4, 42%), [Cu3(phis)3(ClO4)]2+ (m/z 512.4, 37%), [Hphis·H3O]+ (m/z 263.4, 35%), [Cu(phis)(ClO4) − H]+ (m/z 408, 19%), [Cu2(phis)2(ClO4)]+ (m/z 716.8, 18%), and [Cu3(phis)3(ClO4)2]+ (m/z 1123.8, 15%). On the other hand, the organometallic MCs reported by Severin have been found to maintain their structure in solution while showing selectivity toward Li+ and Na+. To our surprise, 1 with similar structural features did not yield the NaCu3 compound. It appears that the lability of these inorganic MCs in hydrophilic solvents is responsible for the observed behavior.
elements.clean_text: The ES mass spectrum of 3 exhibits a major band at m/z 408 originating from the [Cu(phisH)(ClO4)]+ ion while the ES mass spectrum of 2 in MeOH shows the presence of various dissociated species including [Cu(phis)(MeOH)3(H2O)]+ (m/z 422.1, 100%), [Cu2phis)2]2+ (m/z 309.2, 46%), [Cu3(phis)3(ClO4)]2+ (m/z 512.7, 30%), [Hphis⋅H3O]+ (m/z 263.4, 25%), [Cu2(phis)2(ClO4)]+ (m/z 716.9, 17%), [Cu3(phis)3(ClO4)2]+ (m/z 1123.9, 17%), and [Cu(phis)(CH3CN)(H2O)]+ (m/z 368, 15%). The ES-MS of 1 also exhibits the presence of several dissociated species such as [Cu(phis)(CH3CN)(H2O)]+ (m/z 368, 100%), [Cu2phis)2]2+ (m/z 309.2, 60%), [Cu(phis)(ClO4)(MeOH)2(H3O)]+ (m/z 492.4, 42%), [Cu3(phis)3(ClO4)]2+ (m/z 512.4, 37%), [Hphis⋅H3O]+ (m/z 263.4, 35%), [Cu(phis)(ClO4) - H]+ (m/z 408, 19%), [Cu2(phis)2(ClO4)]+ (m/z 716.8, 18%), and [Cu3(phis)3(ClO4)2]+ (m/z 1123.8, 15%). On the other hand, the organometallic MCs reported by Severin have been found to maintain their structure in solution while showing selectivity toward Li+ and Na+. To our surprise, 1 with similar structural features did not yield the NaCu3 compound. It appears that the lability of these inorganic MCs in hydrophilic solvents is responsible for the observed behavior.

metadata.title: Influence of the Li+ on the Structure of the [Cu3(phis)3]3+ Cation
